title: 112_hr2779
content: SECTION 1. TREATMENT OF AFFILIATE TRANSACTIONS. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to exclude certain transactions from the definition of a swap for clearing, execution, margin, capital requirements, and reporting purposes. The Commodity Exchange Act excludes specific transactions from being classified as swaps for reporting purposes if entered into by parties that report information on a consolidated basis. These transactions must be reported to a swap data repository. The Commodity Exchange Act requires reporting of certain transactions to a swap data repository or the Commission within a specified time period. The Commission may establish public reporting requirements for covered transactions between affiliates. The Commodity Exchange Act mandates reporting of transactions to a swap data repository or the Commission within a set timeframe. Regulators of insurance funds can protect fund integrity but cannot impose clearing, execution, margin, capital, or reporting requirements on specific agreements, contracts, or transactions. The text chunk discusses the preservation of federal reserve act authority and federal and state regulatory authorities in relation to certain transactions described in the Act. It clarifies that these transactions are not exempt from certain sections of the Federal Reserve Act or safety-and-soundness authorities of the Federal banking agencies. The text chunk clarifies the authority of banks and state insurance regulators over insurers in relation to swaps, as defined by specific laws. The Commission may prescribe rules to prevent evasion of regulations. The Commission has the authority to define swaps and prevent evasion of regulations through prescribed rules. Securities Exchange Act of 1934 Amendments address affiliate transactions for clearing and execution requirements. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 Amendments address clearing and execution requirements for security-based swaps, excluding certain agreements from the definition of a security-based swap. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 Amendments require reporting of agreements, contracts, or transactions related to consolidated financial statements to a security-based swap data repository or the Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 Amendments mandate reporting of transactions related to financial statements to a swap data repository or the Commission within a specified timeframe. This provision does not exempt transactions from certain Federal Reserve Act sections or prevent insurance fund regulators from safeguarding fund integrity. The provision does not exempt security-based swap transactions between affiliated companies from certain regulatory requirements, including clearing and execution, margin and capital, and reporting requirements. It also does not affect the safety-and-soundness authorities of Federal banking agencies over banks established in law other than title VII. The Commission may prescribe rules to prevent evasion in the context of banks, insurers, and security-based swaps as defined by specific laws. The Commission may prescribe rules to prevent evasion in defining security-based swaps under specific laws. The amendments made by this Act to the Commodity Exchange Act shall be implemented without regard to certain provisions, through an interim final rule with public comment, limited to changes directly related to the amendments. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
